author: cookingboy
body:
According to most on this sub BABA is a lying company with a fake financials and negative revenue and Jack Ma is a Chinese intelligence agent who got rich because he's Winnie the Pooh's cousin and your stock is going to 0 soon.

Or maybe that China is a super large and fast growing economy with very incomplete and bare bone regulations thus gave rises to countless shady businesses but at the same time also cultivated some real world class companies. So investment requires a lot more due diligences but the market also contains exciting opportunities.

But nah, the world is very black and white and this sub’s two dimensional coin only has one side.

author: TruthLayFallen
body:
Just wanted to share what I'd noticed among the community compared to my plays. Maybe it will help some people out. The biggest thing in the last 4 weeks that I noticed was how many questions are asked by people who seem to want to be told what to put their money on. Which is fine, I tend to make a list of what's on a lot of radars as well. But when it came to making purchases, I needed the "why." But I saw many reply with a "Okay, im in @ .85!" just a minute later, no questions asked. Please, just take 20 minutes, hell even 5 minutes of your time to do some digging. Go to the company's website, see if they have anything coming up on the calendar. Something. It makes all the difference in the world to have a clue about what you're getting into and your chances of it moving for better or worse. I felt awful about quite a few people selling IZEA Thursday morning because they wanted to cut their losses, though I had been holding IZEA since the previous week EXACTLY for Thursday afternoon because that was on the calendar.

I'm not trying to be someone who knows better than another, I just don't want to see any of you guys getting yourselves screwed. The stronger we get as a community, the stronger we get as a whole. So take some time to Google/YouTube a few things. MACD, VWAP, MA, Volume, anything you don't have a full grasp on. It'll just add to your ass kicking arsenal and bolster your stock decisions.

Lastly, sorry for being long winded, but DON'T STAY IN FOR SOMETHING BIGGER. If your % goes up, take it. Don't think about what it could have been, take what it IS and gtfo. Even a little gain is still money added to your earnings. I'd take small gains forever over gambling on what ifs. Greed + emotions = BAD.

author: PhillipJFry3020
body:
SPX has moved between the 50 and 200 day MA for the past 21 straight sessions. That has only happened 29 times since 1928, and 21 of those times it tanked below the 50 day MA. So the odds are 72% that the SPX drops below the 50 day MA. 

Even if it beats those odds, the median annual return for that following year was -9.2%.

author: Randomness898
body:
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/23/amazon-google-microsoft-reportedly-providing-web-services-to-blacklisted-china-firms.html

Money talks. There is 0% chance stocks like BABA will actually be forced by the government to get delisted. If they do delist, it'll be voluntary by them if they think they are undervalued here in the US (in which case, they'll actually pay you a premium - like a buyout - to the stock price). The law was created for "show" but it won't have any bark. 

BABA's largest holders are Softbank, TRowe Price, and Blackrock. It's largest individual shareholders are Jack Ma and Joe Tsai, who owns the Nets. Too much influence.

author: dvdmovie1
body:
What are you paying with when you're using Apple Pay, Samsung Pay, Google Pay, etc? Which network does Apple Card run on (Mastercard's) etc etc etc. Visa is working with Tencent.

This "digital gonna end Visa and Mastercard" argument has gone on for years now (I don't know wtf it is but I've read so many of these calls about both companies for years - "Apple Pay is gonna end Visa" - well, you aren't using your Apple Card on Apple Pay and Apple doesn't want to be regulated like a financial entity in this country, does it?) and it both underestimates the moat of both and ignores the innovation, deals and other things that both companies have been working on. Does Venmo have fraud protection?  Venmo and Zelle have had major issues with fraud (https://www.marketwatch.com/story/venmo-takes-losses-after-payments-fraud-2018-11-24, https://techcrunch.com/2018/02/16/zelle-users-are-finding-out-the-hard-way-theres-no-fraud-protection/)  Edit: literally "Venmo does not offer buyer or seller protection" (https://venmo.com/about/security/)

author: seattle_exile
body:
We have 3 main credit card processors in the US - Mastercard, Visa and American Express. Both Mastercard and Visa are similar in how much they charge the vendor per transaction. American Express charges more. 

American Express (historically) was a "charge" card, not a "credit" card. Such a card theoretically had no balance limit (though they could ultimately deny you), but the whole balance was due every month. There was no interest charge, and it had a number of benefits for card holders - free plane tickets, no foreign transaction fees, etc. This made it very attractive to people who could afford to pay their entire balance every month. Therefore, it has a reputation as being for "elites."

However, this has changed over the years. Because of their charges to the vendor, many places don't accept American Express, and others (like Costco) made aggressive arrangements for transactions to become an exclusive provider. Benefits have been cut, especially the ones like free flights that made having a card so attractive. They have been losing more and more business to Visa and MC over the years.

In the context of this story, almost every vendor accepts Visa, while many do not accept Amex. Even places that don't accept Visa always accept a Visa debit card (which is tied to a bank account). Neiman Marcus' inventory is expensive, and it would really not be prudent to carry around an amount of cash that would be required for a shopping trip there. ATMs generally only let you take out about $300 per day. So in so many ways, what they were saying was "if you aren't well-to-do enough to have an American Express card, we don't want your business."

author: Meymo
body:
Credit cards have many advantages over cash. To name a few:
- cash back on all purchases (1-2%, depending on the card). That’s a permanent discount just for using the card
- fraud protection / zero liability for unauthorized transactions
- extended warranties with certain cards

Being Cashless is just you using your credit card to make a purchase. Additionally, you can store your credit card on your phone and tap your phone at many merchant locations.

Visa, Amex, Mastercard and discover benefit from a cashless society

author: dvdmovie1
body:
The card companies that issue credit do (AXP/COF/DFS) and those companies are still down significantly (AXP) or massively (DFS) YTD. The networks (V/MA) are either -9% (Visa) or flat (Mastercard) while the companies that do issue credit are down between around 35% (AXP) and a bit over 50% (Discover) YTD.

The networks have been the best investments (and really is a beautiful toll road business model) for years now and during this - not surprisingly - have held up much better.

author: shuttdown700
body:
To be fair, V and MA are tech stocks. They do financial services and don’t issue credit. They are just financial tech stocks. 

Also, you have to think what’s gonna be big in the next five years. Cloud computing (AMZN, MSFT, GOOG, ADBE, and NVDA for hardware), enterprise tech platforms (MSFT, CRM, GOOG, ADBE, even AAPL and FB), video games (EA, ATVI, MSFT, NVDA, and FB has oculus)... I can continue but you get it. 

Tech has a lower cost for growth and the lowest entry threshold for obtaining economies of scale than physical retailers or businesses with complex supply chains.

author: Night_capn_Mc2oz
body:
I'm trying a simple strategy - three days of daily higher lows and higher highs from a day closing above 5-day MA if the ETF is still above 5 day. The ETF trading below 200 day MA. Buy short on the close. Odds should be around 75-80%. I'm using an inverse ETF 3x to short. Reverse for bullish positions. 
I tired this with QQQ (short) which was in violation of the below 200 day MA rule. Got rekt. Don't short QQQ.

author: Coolegespam
body:
I mean, spy just dipped bellow the 13 day MA. Volume is elevated (compared to the past two months), but noting exceptional. Post-Market is also down, so buyers aren't really stepping in yet. I don't know. News wasn't great today, but I think people are just taking profit. It will probably bounce around the 25 day MA, ~282. If it breaks that tomorrow... The 50 MA is around 271, which would be the next likely bounce.

The market is weakening, and things look over bought. But so long as buyers are stepping up, the market can stay inflated. 

If futures aren't down horribly in the morning, I'd look at buying calls if spy hits 283 for target about 287. We'll possibly get 2 green days out of this, so expiration 5/15 or 5/18, and unload before close. Maybe pickup a few puts early on around 270 with expiration in early June, JIC it does break the 25 day MA. Though, I think the ship might have sallied on that, given the price.

That would be my play on this.

author: Dakstar
body: RH is much easier to someone newer to trading. Webull is much more powerful as a trading platform. You can view a bunch of different indicator overlays: MA, RSI, etc. The desktop app has a solid market screener. But, it takes time to learn what you like and put all that info to use. Honestly, I would just go with what you are comfortable with. Nothing wrong with RH. You do miss out on some extended hours trade availability. But if that doesn't bother you just go with what you like. I used RH for 2 years before moving to Webull about 2 months ago.
